ProjectData.projectName: Mangrove Plantation Initiative in Sundarbans, India

ProjectNamesArray.label: Mangrove Plantation Initiative in Sundarbans, India

ProjectList.project_name: Mangrove Plantation Initiative in Sundarbans, India
ProjectList.project_description: The Sundarbans Mangrove Forest, recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is the world's largest coastal mangrove ecosystem, spanning approximately 10,000 square kilometers across parts of India. This unique ecosystem plays a critical role in climate regulation, coastal protection, and carbon sequestration, while supporting an incredible diversity of flora and fauna. It is home to endangered species such as the Bengal tiger, estuarine crocodiles, and numerous bird species, making it a biodiversity hotspot.  This project focuses on restoring degraded areas within the Sundarbans Mangrove Forest, with activities aimed at enhancing the resilience and biodiversity of the ecosystem. Restoration efforts will include planting mangrove species, rehabilitating damaged habitats, and improving the natural regeneration of the forest. These activities will contribute to increasing the carbon sequestration potential of the area, further strengthening its role in mitigating climate change.In addition to Restoration, the project will engage local communities in sustainable mangrove management practices, ensuring long-term benefits for both the environment and the people who depend on the forest for their livelihoods.
It is an International Biosphere Reserve in the Western Ghats in the Nilgiri Hill Ranges and was included in the UNESCO World Heritage sites in 2012.
